title: Contributingâ€‹
content: The Learning Hub is a community project and we welcome contributions from anyone. If you would like to contribute, please see our contributing guidelines.

title: Reporting Bugsâ€‹
content: If you encounter a bug while using the site, please check the issue tracker to see if it has already been reported. If it hasn't, please open a new issue and provide as much information as you can about the bug.

title: Suggesting Enhancementsâ€‹
content: If you have an idea for a new feature or an improvement to an existing feature, please check the issue tracker to see if it has already been suggested. If it hasn't, please open a new issue and describe your idea.

title: Your First Code Contributionâ€‹
content: If you're looking to make your first code contribution, take a look at the issues labeled good first issue. These issues are relatively easy to resolve and are a good way to get familiar with the project.

title: Pull Requestsâ€‹
content: Fork the repository and create your branch from main.Add your feature.Issue that pull request!

title: Git Commit Messagesâ€‹
content: We are using conventional commits. (feat: add maplibre tutorial) Please see this page for more information.Prefix the commit message with one of the following tags: feat: A new featurefix: A bug fixdocs: Documentation only changesstyle: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing semi-colons, etc)refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a featureperf: A code change that improves performancetest: Adding missing or correcting existing testschore: Changes to the build process or auxiliary tools and libraries such as documentation generation Try to use the present tense ("add feature" not "added feature")Try to use the imperative mood ("move cursor to..." not "moves cursor to...")Limit the first line to 72 characters or lessReference issues and pull requests liberally after the first line

title: Code of Conductâ€‹
content: Please note that this project is released with a Contributor Code of Conduct. By participating in this project you agree to abide by its terms.

title: Examples
content: Examples Here you can find examples of how to use various mapping libraries.

title: Leaflet Live Editing test
content: Leaflet Live Editing test This is an example of a Leaflet map with live editing. To get this to work, you need to create a react component that renders the map, and then use the LiveHtmlEditor tag to render it. Loading...

title: Intro to MapLibre.gl
content: Intro to MapLibre.gl MapLibre.gl is a suite of open-source libraries for embedding interactive, customizable maps in web and mobile applications. It's built on top of Mapbox GL JS and Mapbox Android SDK, and it's designed to be compatible with Mapbox APIs and services.

title: Introductionâ€‹
content: GeoJson.io is a free, open-source tool for quickly creating, viewing, and sharing maps. It's a great way to get started with mapping, and it's also a powerful tool for experienced mappers looking to create custom maps.

title: Getting Startedâ€‹
content: Visit geojson.io to get started. You'll see a map of the world, along with a toolbar on the right side of the screen.

title: Getting Startedâ€‹
content: If you're new to mapping, start here. We've curated a collection of resources designed to help beginners get up to speed.  Intro to Geojson.ioIntro to MapLibre
